article:
The 'tolerance paradox' arises from a problem that a tolerant person might be
antagonistic toward [[Ethnic intolerance|intolerance]], hence intolerant of it.
The tolerant individual would then be by definition intolerant of intolerance.

Karl Popper Karl Popper, The Open Society and Its Enemies, Vol. 1, Notes to
the Chapters: Ch. 7, Note 4 and John Rawls, [http://books.google.com-
/books?id=TdvHKizvuTAC&pg=PA216&lpg=PA216#v=onepage&q=&f=false J. Rawls, A
Theory of Justice, Harvard University Press, 1971, p. 216] have discussed
this paradox.
